entry.author: By Darrell Preston
entry.headline: General Motors'' Municipal Debt Holders Are in Limbo
entry.body:
Municipal bondholders with $700 million of General Motors Corp.-backed debt will have to wait until the company develops a plan to exit bankruptcy to find out how much, if anything, will be repaid.

GM, the largest manufacturer to go bankrupt, has used the municipal bond market to pay for features at plants from Michigan to Georgia. The Detroit-based carmaker''s plan for repayment is still being evaluated, and a decision will be made by the time a new company is formed to emerge from bankruptcy, said GM spokeswoman Julie Gibson.

The investors are in limbo, said Richard Lehmann, a registered investment adviser in Miami Lakes, Florida, and president of Income Securities Advisors Inc. There''s real concern for the bondholders.

Unsecured corporate bondholders will share in a 10 percent stake in the new GM when the company emerges from Chapter 11 bankruptcy, according to court documents. The new government-controlled GM will keep major assets of the old company. GM backed 15 bond issues in eight states totaling just over $700 million, Bloomberg data show.

There is uncertainty about what''s going to happen in bankruptcy, said Dan Solender, who oversees $10 billion as director of municipal bond management at Lord Abbett Co. in Jersey City, New Jersey. His firm owns about $7 million of GM-backed bonds in Ohio and Michigan, according to Bloomberg data.

Tax Exempt

Federal laws allow state and local governments to lend their names to corporations wanting to sell tax-exempt debt for specific types of facilities at plants such as pollution-control or sewer systems.

The municipalities that allow their names to be used to sell the debt don''t bear any liability for repayment. So far, none of the General Motors-backed debt has missed any payments, according to Bloomberg data. A June 1 payment due for bonds sold for pollution-control equipment at a facility in Fort Wayne, Indiana, was made, according to Bloomberg data.

Repayment will hinge, as it has in other bankruptcies involving corporate-backed municipal debt, on whether GM decides to keep an asset funded with the debt in the company going forward, said James Spiotto, a partner and municipal bankruptcy expert with the law firm of Chapman Cutler in Chicago.

Until it is clear what''s going to happen with the assets, you can''t predict what''s going to happen with the debt, Spiotto said.

Anticipating Bankruptcy

Prices of some GM-backed municipal bonds had fallen in recent months to less than 10 cents on the dollar, Bloomberg data show, as investors sold the debt in anticipation of bankruptcy. Those prices are similar to unsecured benchmark GM corporate bonds, which have risen since the filing.

GM-backed municipal debt has risen since the filing earlier this week. A GM-backed bond for a solid waste disposal facility at a plant in Moraine, Ohio, traded at 9.75 cents on the dollar in April. After the filing it rose as high as 15 cents.

The prices are based on investors'' estimates about how much debt in the new company will be worth, said John Miller, chief investment officer of Nuveen Asset Management in Chicago. Nuveen, which has about $115 billion under management, sold its GM-backed municipal securities earlier this year.

Fifteen cents on the dollar is probably pretty close to what GM''s unsecured obligations are worth today, Miller said.

entry.author: By Adam L. Freeman and Francesca Cinelli
entry.headline: Generali, L''Espresso, Telecom Italia: Italian Equity Preview
entry.body:
The following companies may have unusual price changes in Italian trading. Stock symbols are in parentheses and share prices are from the previous close.

Italy''s FTSE MIB (FTSEMIB) Index advanced 576.53, or 3.12 percent, to 19,040.59.

Assicurazioni Generali SpA (G) : Bank of America Corp. upgraded Italy''s biggest insurer to neutral from underperform. The shares added 47 cents, or 3.3 percent, to 14.6 euros.

Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena (BMPS IM): Italy''s third-largest bank is scheduled to hold an extraordinary shareholders'' meeting to approve new governance and compensation rules. The shares rose 3 cents, or 2.7 percent, to 1.10 euros.

Fiat SpA (ISP) : Morgan Stanley said in a note today it''s increasing its conviction on overweight-rated Fiat ahead of second-quarter results. The brokerage said that market hype around Fiat''s drive for consolidation has calmed following its failure to acquire Opel.

Fiat added 19 cents, or 2.9 percent, to 6.82 euros.

Gruppo Editoriale L''Espresso SpA (ES) : The Italian publisher hired lawyers to explore legal action against Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi related to remarks in which he allegedly invited companies to boycott advertising in La Repubblica newspaper. The publisher''s stock climbed 9 cents, or 8.25 percent, to 1.14 euros.

Safilo Group SpA (SFL) : Moody''s Investors Service downgraded Safilo''s Corporate Family Rating to Caa2 from B3, and the Probability of Default Rating to Caa3 from Caa1.

Separately, Standard Poor''s Ratings Services lowered its long-term corporate credit rating to CC from CCC+. The outlook is negative.

Shares of the world''s second-largest maker of eyewear added 2.9 cents, or 6.4 percent, to 47.95 cents.

Telecom Italia SpA (TIT) : Goldman Sachs Group Inc. added Italy''s biggest phone company to its conviction buy list, citing its strong re-rating potential. The shares gained 1.25 cents, or 1.3 percent, to 94.85 cents.

UniCredit SpA (UCG) : Chief Executive Officer Alessandro Profumo will speak at a Rome event organized by the bank. The shares advanced 9.6 cents, or 5.5 percent, to 1.84 euros.
